notes:
1. Moment of a Force

The moment of a force about a point is the measure of its tendency to rotate the body about that point.

  • Scalar Formulation (2D): $M_O = Fd$, where $d$ is the perpendicular distance from point O to the line of action of the force.
  • Vector Formulation (3D): $\mathbf{M}_O = \mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{F}$, where $\mathbf{r}$ is a position vector from O to any point on the line of action of $\mathbf{F}$.

2. Couple

A couple consists of two parallel forces that are equal in magnitude, opposite in direction, and non-collinear. A couple produces a pure rotation (moment) with zero net force.

The moment of a couple ($M$) is $F \times d$, where $d$ is the perpendicular distance between the forces. This moment is a free vector; it acts effectively at any point on the rigid body.

3. Equivalent Systems

Any system of forces and moments can be reduced to a single resultant force acting at a specific point and a resultant couple moment. This is known as an equivalent force-couple system.

Specifically, a force $\mathbf{F}$ acting at point A can be moved to point B if a couple moment $\mathbf{M} = \mathbf{r}_{BA} \times \mathbf{F}$ is added to the system to account for the eccentric effect.

solvedExamples.question: A force of 50 N acts tangentially on the rim of a wheel with a radius of 0.4 m. What is the moment of this force about the center of the wheel?
solvedExamples.explanation: The force is tangent to the rim, so the radius is perpendicular to the line of action. The moment arm is the radius. $M = Fd = 50 \text{ N} \times 0.4 \text{ m} = 20$ N·m.

solvedExamples.question: Which of the following is a property of a couple moment?

options.text: It depends on the point about which moments are taken.
It produces translation of the body.

solvedExamples.explanation: A couple moment is a free vector, meaning its effect on a rigid body is the same regardless of where it is applied. It causes pure rotation and has a zero resultant force.

solvedExamples.question: Replacing a force acting at a point A with an equal parallel force acting at point B requires adding:
solvedExamples.explanation: Moving a force's line of action to a new parallel position changes its rotational effect. To maintain equivalency, a couple moment equal to the moment of the original force about the new point B must be added.
